{"step_by_step_thinking": "Positive fecal occult blood tests indicate the presence of blood in the stool, which can be a sign of gastrointestinal bleeding. In this case, the patient is asymptomatic but has a family history of large intestinal cancer, which increases the suspicion for a neoplastic cause. The colonoscopy reveals a polyp in the descending colon, which is a common location for adenomatous polyps. Excisional biopsy of the polyp shows 75% tubular architecture, which is consistent with an adenomatous polyp. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is B. Adenomatous polyp.", "answer_choice": "B"}
